news.title: Woman filmed in viral video brutally assaulting stepdaughter arrested for murder
news.content:
By Tapiwa Svondo

THE Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) has confirmed the arrest of 20-year-old Memory Moyana for the brutal assault of her stepdaughter, a minor, in a toilet at Chizhanje, Mabvuku, Zimbabwe.

The arrest follows the circulation of a disturbing video on social media showing the violent incident.

In a statement, the ZRP national spokesperson, Commissioner Paul Nyathi said Moyana tried to conceal the crime claiming her stepdaughter died following an attack by evil spirits.

Preliminary investigations by the police reveal that the suspect, who was the victims stepmother, attempted to cover up the heinous crime by claiming that the minor had been attacked by evil spirits.

As a result, the baby was taken to a self-proclaimed prophet in Ruwa, where she tragically died.

Moyanas husband is also in trouble after he tried to secretly bury his deceased daughter.

The suspect and her husband, Talent Muchato (26) tried to secretly bury the victim at Mutinhima village, Nyazura on December 17, 2024. A concerned citizen later made a report to the police, said Nyathi.

news.title: Jail pirate taxi drivers and operators- say stakeholders as three killed, 10 injured after overloaded vehicle carrying Apostolic sect members collides with truck
news.content:
By James Muonwa l Mashonaland West Correspondent

THREE people perished while 10 others were injured when an illegal taxi ferrying members of an Apostolic sect going for a New Year crossover gathering side-swiped a truck.

The unfortunate incident, which occurred between Chinhoyi and Lions Den on New Years Eve, has left families without breadwinners and survivors nursing various degrees of wounds.

Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) national spokesperson, Commissioner Paul Nyathi confirmed the accident involving the illegal taxi commonly known as go-faster or mushikashika in vernacular.

The ZRP confirms a fatal road traffic accident which occurred on December 31, 2024, at around 2000 hours at the 136 kilometre peg along Harare -Chirundu road.

Three people were killed while 10 others were injured when an Isuzu KB 250 vehicle with no passengers on board side swiped with a Toyota Probox vehicle with 13 passengers on board, Nyathi said.

Bodies of the victims were taken to Chinhoyi Provincial Hospital mortuary for postmortem while the injured were admitted at the same facility.

REACTIONS TO RECENT FATALITIES

Social media users reacted to news of the accident and heaped blame on police for allowing pirate taxis to make the countrys roads a traffic jungle.

A user @AlderleyNyonga2 questioned how a light motor vehicle, a Toyota Probox with a carrying capacity of an average of seven people, was allowed to have 13 passengers and pass through a police checkpoint.

Another commentator, Amen Mapiya said cops manning roadblocks should be strict and arrest all errant drivers flouting road rules and regulations.

Whats the reason for manning roadblock, why allowing such a car to pass through? Thats a good reason to tow away that car and the driver to pay a heavy fine.

We hope further investigations will be conducted and bring the officers on that roadblock to book for allowing such a car to pass, said Mapiya.

Jerry Maguranyanga said for years he took pride in ZRP as a top policing organisation in Africa but the level of corruption is becoming more apparent.

Carlos Mufiri concurred with Mapuranga, noting the graft was increasingly contributing to road carnage.

ZRP is very toxic. All the police officers at roadblocks along the above-mentioned road knew about the 13 passengers in the car but the driver just paid his way, said Mufiri.

Thirteen passengers, you are not working you guys. What are the reasons for your roadblocks?

Stakeholders interviewed by NewZimbabwe.com in Mashonaland West province called on government to ban pirate taxis plying various routes and introduce regulated conventional buses.

There are pirates that ply the Chinhoyi-Chegutu route while others transit between the provincial capital and Harare, Karoi, Mhangura and other outlying areas such as Kenzamba, Makonde district.

WHAT HAS GIVEN RISE TO PIRATE TAXIS

Since September last year, 13,886 motorists have been arrested nationwide for operating pirate taxis, an indicator of how rampant pirates are in Zimbabwe.

Unregistered taxis have been part of Zimbabwes transportation system for years, but they have increased since the coronavirus pandemic as other legal means of transport fell away, according to the Ministry of Transport and Infrastructural Development.

In 2020, to enforce lockdown measures and discourage people from leaving their homes, the government outlawed the countrys most dependable means of transport: licensed and privately owned omnibuses, minivan taxis  locally known as kombis  and smaller cabs. Only public buses, which are few and unreliable, were allowed to operate.

The ban was lifted in December 2022 but several private operators that had disposed of their vehicles struggled to get back into business. As a result, pirate taxis still dominate the public transportation sector.

Despite various public awareness campaigns to educate passengers on the dangers of using illegal taxis, illegal taxis continue to thrive.

The demographic and geographical growth of Zimbabwean cities has put pressure on public transportation services, according to research from the Harare-based nonprofit Zimbabwe Coalition on Debt and Development (ZIMCODD).

Zimbabwes population has increased by 16.2% and now stands at 15.1 million people, up from the 13 million in the 2012 census.

When there is population growth, our cities then also expand, says Cynthia Huni, an urban planning expert.

You see new suburbs being opened, and when that happens you have to create new roads and transport systems.

While the lack of reliable public transport has created new opportunities for an informal market, Passenger Association of Zimbabwe (PAZ) president, Tafadzwa Goliati believes the influx of pirate taxis also stems from the countrys economic hardships characterised by high unemployment.

There is general poverty and joblessness in this country and people are not earning much to survive, so they find alternatives to make ends meet  and pirate taxis is one of those means, Goliati says.

ADVOCACY FOR JAILING OF MUSHIKASHIKA DRIVERS, OPERATORS

Just like commuter omnibuses were outlawed for causing road traffic accidents, some stakeholders are also calling on the government to deal harshly with mushikashika and jail those who operate them.

Last September, government implemented the radius-based restrictions for commuter omnibuses from 120 km to 60 km, a move aimed at improving road safety on the countrys major roads.This applied to commuter omnibuses with a seating capacity of 26 passengers and below.

Transport and Infrastructural Development Minister Felix Mhona said the move was aimed at mitigating against road traffic accidents involving kombis.

The minister argued that high-capacity buses had greater leg space and baggage space for long-distance travellers than kombis, which makes buses more ideal for long-distance journeys.

A member of Women Coalition of Zimbabwe (WiCOZ), Mary-Anne Mutsambi said besides being sexually violated in crammed pirate taxis, the speeding vessels put the lives of breadwinners at high risk of leaving their children orphaned.

I am personally advocating for a total ban on mushikashika and incarceration of drivers and owners. Pirate taxis have become death traps, and we are needlessly losing lives and limbs daily.

The pirates are notorious for overloading passengers like sardines, speeding, hailing insults and profanities as well as flouting road rules and regulations with abandon recklessness at the expense of passengers lives and wellbeing, therefore imprisonment of drivers and operators is the only way to make our roads safer and saner, said Mutsambi.

news.title: Persons with albinism face severe health crisis in Zimbabwe as lack of access to care claims another life
news.content:
By Thandiwe Garusa

PERSONS with albinism in Zimbabwe continue to die as they face severe lack of access to critical healthcare and resources, an activist has said.

Marvellous Tshuma, activist for people living with albinism and co-founder of Noble Hands Zimbabwe Trust, a charity organisation that deals with people with disabilities, orphans and widows narrated how Chipo Chigova (35) from the rural areas of Gweru died after a long battle with skin cancer.

According to Tshuma, the late Chigova was a mother of seven in a polygamous family and she worked at Romac Farm for most of her life doing demanding piece jobs such as cutting firewood and weeding fields.

Chigova has also left behind a 9-month-old baby.

She never had access to sunscreen or sufficient information about skin cancer.

Access to sunscreen lotions and other skin care needs was a huge challenge that she depended on Vaseline (petroleum jelly) or nothing at all.

We reached out to her in 2023 through the Albinism Konnect and tried to get her treated unfortunately that time she was pregnant, and treatment was halted.

In 2024, when she gave birth, we again pushed for treatment, but the cancer had advanced, and she was now in a palliative state.

She stopped breastfeeding at three months. From time-to-time we were now sending food, medication and lotions but it was not enough, cancer kept growing.

The current drought made things worse for them, that even in her state she would try to go for piece jobs until around June 2024 when she was now bedridden.

She endured extreme pain during her last days. Because she didnt get sunscreen, early screening and treatment we lost her, an emotional Tshuma said.

The activist also bemoaned neglect from the government and called for the establishment of regular skin cancer screenings, at least twice a year.

She is also lobbying for hospitals and clinics to have at least one staffer professionally trained in albinism-related health issues.

l am traumatised because of what l see in the countryside, brothers and sisters dying without treatment. The fundraisers we do are only a drop in the ocean.

The Government of Zimbabwe has abdicated its duty especially to my community of persons with albinism.

We need regular skin screening at least two times a year. Hospitals and clinics must have at least one health professional knowledgeable about albinism and skin cancer for early referrals, she added.

Chigovas passing shows the harsh reality for many in rural Zimbabwe, where treatable and preventable illnesses often lead to death because of neglect.

news.title: Scandal ridden Zimbabwean referees left out of CHAN tournament
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

TAINTED Zimbabwean referees have been left out of the Confederation of African Footballs (CAF) list of officials for the upcoming CHAN finals in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania.

The tournament kicks off on the first of February, with the final set for the 28th of that month.

Once a continental powerhouse in terms of refereeing, Zimbabwe has collapsed on the perking order over the years.

A total of 65 referees was shared by CAF this Friday, with officials from lowly-ranked countries making it ahead of Zimbabweans.

Social media users blamed their absence on poor officiating in the Castle Lager premiership, where cases of match manipulation were raised.

A number of questionable calls by centre referees and linesmen alike were topical in the past season, at times leading to abandonment of matches as was the case between Simba Bhora and Highlanders prematurely ended Chibuku Super Cup at Wadzanai Stadium.

By week five, the ZIFA referees committee had suspended five officials for dubious officiating.

Of course we are punishing them for their misconduct, our referees make a lot of mistakes.

For your own information we are in week five and we have played 45 matches in the league and of those we have three or four matches in which we felt referees influenced the outcome of the game, said referees boss Norman Matemera after being quizzed on what they were doing to rein in faltering officials.

A FIFA ban that froze out Zimbabwe from international competitions did not do referees any favour too, as they were also scrapped off the global bodys panel.

news.title: Controversial Gift Banda files appeal against ZIFA at Court of Arbitration for Sport
news.content:
By Sport Reporter

CONTROVERSIAL Bulawayo-based businessman Gift Banda has appealed at the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) over his suspension to run for office in the upcoming Zimbabwe Football Association (ZIFA) elections slated for January 25.

Banda was one of the candidates who had submitted names to contest for the vice presidency, only to fail the integrity test, which was the final grading for anyone who wanted to contest in the upcoming polls.

Banda becomes the second disqualified candidate to file an appeal at CAS, the first one being former Warriors striker Benjani Mwaruwari.

I can confirm to you that Gift Banda has also appealed at CAS because we have received a written notification from the international legal board.

So, we now have two disqualified candidates who have appealed at the present moment, the other one being Benjani Mwaruwari, said an inside source at ZIFA.

Bandas bid to run for the upcoming elections has been marred with controversy. Last month, he was arrested on allegations of submitting forged Ordinary Level certificates at ZIFA as part of his documents.

Banda is seeking a return at ZIFA after serving as the organisations substantive president when Zimbabwe was serving a FIFA ban.

Meanwhile, former Norton Member of Parliament Temba Mliswa has also threatened to appeal and challenge his disqualification to run for office in the upcoming elections.

Mliswa revealed this via his X account but at the present moment NewZimbabwe.com can confirm that he is het to submit his papers at CAS.

Besides Mliswa, close sources have also revealed that another aspiring ZIFA presidential candidate prophet Walter Magaya is also set to take the same legal route against ZIFA following his disqualification.

news.title: Mnangagwa in mini-Cabinet reshuffle, appoints new CIO Director-General
news.content:
By Tapiwa Svondo

PRESIDENT Emmerson Dambudzo Mnangagwa has announced the reassignment of two key ministers and the appointment of a new Director-General of the Presidents Department, effective immediately.

In a statement by the Chief Secretary to the President and Cabinet, Martin Rushwaya, former Public Service Minister July Moyo has been reassigned to the Minister of Energy and Power Development portfolio, while Edgar Moyo was switched to Moyos former post, with immediate effect.

In terms of Subsection 1 of Section 104 of the Constitution of Zimbabwe, His Excellency the President, Cde. Dr. Emmerson Dambudzo Mnangagwa has reassigned the under-listed Ministers as follows:

Hon. J.G. Moyo, M.P. Minister of Energy and Power Development.

Hon. E. Moyo, M.P. Minister of Public Service, Labour and Social Welfare.

The re-assignments are with immediate effect, said Rushwaya

July Moyo has been reassigned to Energy portfolio

Additionally, Mnangagwa also appointed Zimbabwe National Parks and Wildlife Authority (ZimParks) Director-General Fulton Mangwanya as the new as the new Director-General of the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO) also known as the Presidents Department. He replaced Isaac Moyo.

In terms of Section 226(1) of the Constitution of Zimbabwe, His Excellency the President, Cde. Dr. Emmerson Dambudzo Mnangagwa has appointed Dr. Fulton Mangwanya as the Director General, Presidents Department. The appointment is with immediate effect, said Rushwaya.

In his latest interview with State media, the 82-year-old Zanu PF leader, who is reportedly planning to run for a third presidential term, hinted on ringing changes to his team of Cabinet ministers amid reports the redeployments will extend to the securocrats sector.

news.title: New Police Commissioner-General Mutamba officially takes over command
news.content:
By Anna Chibamu

THE new Commissioner-General of Police, Stephen Mutamba this Friday officially took over the reins of the countrys police service at a colourful ceremony held in Harare.

Mutamba replaced Godwin Matanga, who was retired on January 1, 2025.

President Mnangagwa, for unknown reasons, recently retired Matanga and elevated his deputy to assume overall leadership at Police General Headquarters (PGHQ).

Speaking during a handover-and-takeover event at Mkushi Depot (formerly Morris Depot) in Harare this Friday, Matanga dispelled rumour that he wanted to cling on to his lofty post citing irregularities in his retirement procedure.

Matanga said he was properly served with notice of his retirement by Mnangagwas office, quashing rumour that he had reported for duty after his dismissal from the service.

May l take this opportunity to clarify an incorrect position that has been peddled in the media recently pertaining to my retirement.

Ladies and gentlemen, listen carefully, I was properly served by the President of the Republic of Zimbabwe, His Excellency Cde Dr. E.D. Mnangagwa at a time when my retirement was due, he explained.

His utterances cleared the air after social media reported the outgoing police chief had dramatically reported for duty, claiming he was not properly dismissed.

The outgoing police chief said he was delighted to address officers and officials witnessing the change of guard.

For me personally, it is a boundless moment of delight as I bid farewell to longstanding colleagues to an organisation that I served over a long period of time.

Alas, the day will certainly come when we have to separate from the organisation that we have so much and equally drew a lot of friendships, experiences and livelihoods

Allow me, therefore, to express my heartfelt gratitude to His Excellency the President of the Republic of Zimbabwe Cde Emmerson Dambudzo Mnangagwa for according me the privilege to serve the nation in the Office of the Commissioner General Police.

He added: I am grateful for his guidance and indeed the security infrastructure for their enduring support during my tenure. More importantly, my sincere gratitude goes to the general public of Zimbabwe, my regional peers and the regional police chiefs and the media for the support they rendered to my tenure.

I am, however, confident that a new broom sweeps clean, and my successor will be able to ride on my achievements that we have made and tackle existing challenges head on.

I am comforted to pass the baton to Cde Stephen Mutamba whom l have been with in the trenches for so many years and have known his capacity to steer the ship going forward.

Matanga thanked all the deputy Commissioner Generals and junior ranking cops for their unwavering support during his tenure.

I wish to also thank all senior officers and junior officers and members of the police service who shared and advanced the vision of the organisation through the provision of quality police service to the people of our great nation, he added.

I am so content with the contribution and service l gave to the country in pursuit of national goals and aspirations.

In attendance at the historic handover-and-takeover ceremony was Home Affairs Minister Kazembe Kazembe, State Security Minister Lovemore Matuke, CIO boss Isaac Moyo, Army Commander Anselem Sanyatwe and Air Marshall Jacob Nzvede.

Prior to the Friday event, an organisation claiming to represent children of war veterans, COZWA, made sensational allegations that Matanga reported at his Harare offices in full police uniform arguing he was yet to receive official communication of his marching orders.

COZWA proceeded to make sensational claims that the polices Support Unit, Alpha Troop had been put on standby to forcibly remove him from office.

news.title: Man arrested at Beitbridge border, driving ‘stolen’ luxury BMW into Zimbabwe
news.content:
By IOL

A 40-year-old foreign national is expected to appear in court after he allegedly tried to drive a luxury BMW across the border into Zimbabwe on New Years Eve.

Police said officers were on duty at the Beitbridge Port of Entry when they spotted a man driving a black BMW G70, 7 Series, valued at over R2 million. The man wanted to drive over into Zimbabwe.

The man had a South African passport. Preliminary investigation reveals that the vehicle is wanted by one of the banks in South Africa. The driver alleged that the real owner will be flying to South Africa on January 1, said police spokesperson, Lieutenant Colonel Stephen Thakeng.

He said the man was arrested and charged for possession of a suspected stolen vehicle and providing the SAPS with fraudulent documents.

The vehicle was seized. He will appear on January 3 in the Musina Magistrates Court.

Limpopo police commissioner, Lieutenant General Thembi Hadebe applauded the members who were vigilant to ensure that the suspect was brought to book to face the full might of the law.

She added that its the results of more boots on the ground during festive season.

Meanwhile, Deputy Minister of Police, Polly Boshielo, MEC for Community Safety and Transport, Violet Mathye, Vhembe District Executive Mayor, councillor Freda Nkondo and commissioner Hadebe, led the annual Safer Festive Season Operational-Inspection Tour at Musina and Beitbridge Port of Entry.

The visit was part of efforts to fight cross-border crimes.

news.title: Mozambique – The Emerging Southern Africa Energy giant
news.content:
By Noel T Ngangira

Put aside the recent political turmoil, Mozambique set in motion an energy juggernaut plan that left many African nations drooling in awe.

Lets rewind a bit. In 2023, energy exports from coal, gas, and electricity topped US$5.8 billion. Coal led the pack with $3.4 billion, followed by gas at $1.73 billion and electricity ($658 million). 80% of its electricity exports went to SA and 15.4% to Zimbabwe.

With 180 trillion cubic feet of natural gas reserves mainly in the Rovuma Basin off the coast of Cabo Delgado, Mozambique is only bettered by Nigeria (with 203 trillion cubic feet) in Africa. It ranks 14th in the world. Energy giants TotalEnergies (France), Exxon Mobil (USA), Eni (Italy) and CNPC (China) are the key LNG operators in Mozambique.

Cahora Bassa Hydro power station in Tete province has a power generation capacity of 2,075MW, and plans are underway to increase it to 4,000MW. The following hydroelectric power plants are also in the pipeline and will be online between 2027 and 2031: Mphanda Nkuwa, 1,500MW (Tete); Chemba, 1,000 MW (Sofala); Lupata, 650MW (Tete); and Boroma, 210MW (Tete). This is hydropower only; there is solar and thermal to boot.

For comparison, Zimbabwe generates about 1,500MW but has an installed capacity of about 2,240MW (hydro and thermal). According to the 2022 Population and Housing Census, 62% of Zimbabwes population has access to electricity  though its not mentioned how many hours per day was/is the electricity actually available.

According to the International Trade Administration (ITA), Mozambique aims to achieve universal electrification by 2030. Significant strides to achieve this goal have been made. It moved from 34% in 2021 to 48% in 2022 in terms of population with access to electricity. With the investments made and the work in progress, energy for all is within reach for sure.

The Mozambican government plans an additional 14,000MW of green energy (hydro) between 2030 and 2040. In its energy transition strategy document, the government plans a whooping US$80 billion investment in the energy sector by 2050. Serious stuff!

ITA adds that Mozambique has the largest power generation potential of all Southern African countries. Power Africa estimates that the nation could generate 187 gigawatts (187,000MW) of power from coal, hydro, gas, wind, and solar.

Sources include Global Data, Club Mozambique, International Trade Administration (ITA), Power Africa, ADB COP28, and UNICEF.

news.title: SA border authorities working with Zimbabwe to prevent entry of illegal immigrants
news.content:
By SABC

THE Border Management Authority (BMA) says its working with its Zimbabwean counterparts to prevent illegal immigrants from entering South Africa.

BMA Commissioner, Dr Michael Masiapato assessed readiness at the biggest land port, the Beitbridge Border Post, between Zimbabwe and South Africa yesterday ahead of the end of the festive season.

The border post is a critical gateway linking South Africa with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region.

Authorities launched a crime-fighting campaign yesterday to address pressing challenges.

Dr Masiapato says they expect to see an increase in vehicles and people towards the end of the weekend.

With its high volume of travellers and goods, the border post also serves as a hotspot for illicit activities, including the smuggling of contraband.
